meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>axe</radical> is stuck into the <radical>ground</radical> on a <kanji>hill</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine climbing up the hill. The sun is coming up behind the axe,  silhouetting the whole thing very nicely.
reading_mnemonic: You reach the top of the <kanji>hill</kanji> and realize the entire hill is covered in <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (きゅう). The axe has a little note on it that says "Cucumber Hill Axe - Please Use."
reading_hint: You take the axe out of the hill and cut off some cucumber to eat. Mm mm!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>temple</radical> isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a <kanji>samurai</kanji>, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe.
meaning_hint: You walk up to a temple and you're surprised to find that there's a samurai guarding it. Talk to him for a while so he can tell you why he has been doing this job. He's quite a nice guy, actually.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is <reading>samurai</reading>, which should be easy enough to remember.
reading_hint: If you know the meaning you know the reading as well! That doesn't happen too often with kanji, so consider yourself lucky!

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>blade</radical> and the kanji <kanji>blade</kanji> are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: Please, just know your radicals. Please!
reading_mnemonic: When you stab your <kanji>blade</kanji> into an enemy you shout "<reading>Ha</reading> (は)!" It's just the normal "thrusting with blade" sound.
reading_hint: Ha, HA, HaaAA! Those are the blade sounds we all know and love.

meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>vines</radical>, so you <kanji>shout</kanji>! It's hard for you to talk normally, and even harder for people to understand you unless you shout.
meaning_hint: You were born with mouth vines (a rare condition where your mouth is always full of vines), so you've been shouting all your life. And yet people still can't hear you. It's very frustrating.
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>shout</kanji> so that people can understand you through the mouth vines. You shout, "<reading>きょう</reading>と!" because you hear there is a temple there for people with your condition.
reading_hint: Imagine the word きょうと not coming out clearly because of your mouth vines. People can only hear the きょう part, so they don't know where you want to go. SHOUT LOUDER! きょうと！

meaning_mnemonic: From my <radical>mouth</radical> I have told you <radical>seven</radical> times not to do that. Now I have to <kanji>scold</kanji> you.
meaning_hint: SEVEN TIMES! You'd think you'd learn.
reading_mnemonic: What were you doing wrong that caused me to <kanji>scold</kanji> you? You were feeding the <reading>鹿</reading> (しか). If you feed them they'll never be able to feed themselves!
reading_hint: Imagine yourself feeding the deer, then getting scolded (or you doing the scolding to someone else feeding the deer, whichever works best).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>good luck</radical> radical and the <kanji>good luck</kanji> kanji are the same!
meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
reading_mnemonic: For <kanji>good luck</kanji>, you keep special <reading>kits</reading> (きつ) in your <reading>kitch</reading>en (きち). These kitchen kits contain good luck charms.
reading_hint: Your good luck kitchen kits have charms that say things like, "good food," "good company," and "good luck not cutting off your fingers with kitchen knives."

meaning_mnemonic: When <radical>dirt</radical> and <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>suit</radical> one another, the flowers grow so tall that they make a <kanji>tower</kanji>! A flower tower made of flower power!
meaning_hint: Imagine walking in the woods and coming across a huge tower made of flowers. It goes so high you can hardly see the top.
reading_mnemonic: The only place flowers grow into <kanji>tower</kanji>s like this is in <reading>とう</reading>きょう. とうきょう dirt is the best. とうきょう flowers are the best. Thus, you end up with a lot of とうきょう towers.
reading_hint: How do you think the とうきょう tower came to be, anyway? It was once a big flower tower. They just replaced it with metal later. BOOM! History bomb, you're welcome.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>woman</radical> <radical>servant</radical> is the lower ranking <kanji>princess</kanji>. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do.
meaning_hint: Just imagine a princess saying "UGH, I'm just like a servant, I have to do all the crap you tell me." Then, all the servants roll their eyes, because, really, she's a princess, lucky duck.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>princess</kanji> goes on to do whatever she wants. She tells the real servants, "Don't tell my daddy, the king, I did this. <reading>He may</reading> (ひめ) not like it."
reading_hint: The servants all know they should tell the king, because the princess is a servant to the king, just as they are, plus they don't want to lose their heads.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> loves her <radical>catapult</radical> for some good ol' fashioned <kanji>recreation</kanji>.
meaning_hint: You ask the woman what she does for fun... for recreation. She says, she goes out and shoots her catapult.
reading_mnemonic: Her favorite thing to shoot at with her catapult for <kanji>recreation</kanji> is <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご).
reading_hint: Get out of here, Godzilla! I'm gonna shoot you.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>measurement</radical> radical and the <kanji>measurement</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: If you make sure to know the radicals, you'll also make sure to know the kanji too, automagically.
reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>measure</kanji> something... something that will make you famous. You decide you'll measure the biggest mass in our solar system. We're talking about the <reading>sun</reading> (すん).
reading_hint: Imagine yourself deciding to do this. First step is to get a ridiculously long measuring tape. Then, you go up to the <reading>sun</reading> and start measuring. You immediately start getting burned. Feel the pain of the heat from the <reading>sun</reading>. Think about how this really probably wasn't a good idea. You still go forward, though, doing your best to <kanji>measure</kanji> the sun. Ouch, ouch, ouch.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>wind</radical> coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a <kanji>storm</kanji>. Well, it is a storm, really.
meaning_hint: If you think about it makes sense. Those mountain winds that come down from the mountain are cold and windy and nasty. When they mix with warmer air down below, it creates a nasty <kanji>storm</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>storm</kanji> is nothing to scoff at. If you get hit by the storm and get all wet and nasty and electrocuted, you're bound to get <reading>a rash</reading> (あらし).
reading_hint: The rash comes from being wet and not drying off when you get home. Your skin gets irritated by this moisture.

meaning_mnemonic: If someone puts a <radical>blade</radical> to your <radical>heart</radical>, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to <kanji>endure</kanji> the pain and uncomfortableness of the situation.
meaning_hint: Imagine your chest and ribs are open. There's a blade on your heart. Now try not to move, or your heart will be cut!
reading_mnemonic: This is all a part of your <reading>nin</reading>ja (にん) training. You must learn to stay totally still, without breathing. This is how they train you. If you can <kanji>endure</kanji> this you can endure anything, plus you can stay really still, which is good for ninjas.
reading_hint: Just think about how much you want to become a ninja. You'll do anything, even endure this.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> told you that a <radical>flood</radical> last <radical>evening</radical> would <kanji>draw close</kanji>. There was nothing you could do to stop it, it seemed to be <kanji>be imminent</kanji>, coming in the darkness of the evening.
meaning_hint: Think back to last evening, when your fingers twitched and twisted, warning you as the flood started to draw close.
reading_mnemonic: Luckily whenever you sense a flood starting to <kanji>draw close</kanji>, <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) prepares a raft. Remember Satsuki? Such a talented little girl. I guess floods are common enough that she's learned to make rafts?
reading_hint: This one is barely big enough for two people, so you have to draw close if you want to fit. Kind of uncomfortable, but it's better than being caught in an imminent flood.

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> when you're in <radical>private</radical> to use an <radical>arrow</radical> to <kanji>push open</kanji> things.
meaning_hint: You're in private in your own room, no one else is around. Now you wrap your fingers around this big arrow, and you push open your door, your curtains, your windows. It's weird, but you really enjoy this.
reading_mnemonic: Your favorite thing to <kanji>push open</kanji> is your own <reading>eye</reading> (あい). You take the arrow into your fingers and gently push each lid open until you can see.
reading_hint: Picture the arrow in your hands. You're facing a mirror, but you can't see because you're about to push open your eyes. The anticipation is killing you, push them open now!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>ladle</radical> radical and the <kanji>ladle</kanji> kanji are the same!
meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
reading_mnemonic: You use a <kanji>ladle</kanji> to distribute soup. But as you're ladling you find something odd floating in the soup. It's... a <reading>toe</reading> (と)! You scream, dropping the ladle and the toe on the ground.
reading_hint: Your mom comes rushing in and smacks you on the head. "Fool!" she says, "This is toe soup, what did you think you'd ladle up?!" Oops.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>slide</radical> to get off this <radical>jet</radical> is a beautiful, brilliant <kanji>vermilion</kanji> color.
meaning_hint: Vermilion is like an orange red, which is perfect for visibility purposes.
reading_mnemonic: You jump onto the <kanji>vermilion</kanji> slide. It's actually more of a steep <reading>chu</reading>te (しゅ). And... oh... urp... it's making you sick.
reading_hint: The vermilion chute spits you out and you spit out your lunch. And it looks vermilion. Uh oh. Hospital. Please.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> has an <radical>omen</radical> growing from it, one single <kanji>peach</kanji> that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons.
meaning_hint: Of course, this tree omen of a <kanji>peach</kanji> refers to momotaro, the little boy who was born from a peach (you should look it up if you don't know this children's story).
reading_mnemonic: If <reading>momo</reading>taro (もも) wasn't enough, think about the <kanji>peach</kanji> growing larger and larger. You want it to grow bigger, so you yell at it: "<reading>MO</reading>RE! <reading>MO</reading>RE!" (もも).
reading_hint: It grows bigger everytime you say "MORE MORE" twice. If you say it just once, it stays the same.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical> you cut off a <radical>tree</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> is a <kanji>pear</kanji>. I don't know if you've ever seen Asian pears, but they're pretty big and sturdy. You can't just pick them off of the tree, you need the help of a knife. That's why this is a pear, and not an apple or peach or something else.
meaning_hint: Imagine standing below a tree full of pears. You take your knife and carefully cut them all down, one by one.
reading_mnemonic: As you cut the <kanji>pear</kanji>s down, you can't help but <reading>gnash</reading> (なし) your teeth. You want to eat these pears right now. You gnash and grind and wait though, because you want to have them all down before you start the feast.
reading_hint: Imagine a beautiful, ripe pear in your mind. Now gnash your teeth. Mmm. You want to eat a pear right now, don't you?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>animal</radical> that hangs out in <radical>melon</radical> patches is the elusive <kanji>fox</kanji>! They like to steal melons then come back into town disguised as human melon sellers. Foxes are tricky like that.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a red fox scampering through a melon patch trying to take melons with it.
reading_mnemonic: If you want to stop <kanji>fox</kanji>es from stealing your melons you can get one of those <reading>kits</reading> that <reading>neigh</reading> (きつね) when one is around. The kits neigh when they sense a fox, but because it sounds like a horse the fox won't run. But you'll be able to get out there and take your melons back!
reading_hint: Imagine buying kits that neigh and putting them around your melon patch to warn you when foxes are around.

meaning_mnemonic: You put a <radical>stone</radical> into a <radical>wrap</radical> of some kind. This wrap happens to be a <kanji>cannon</kanji>, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason.
meaning_hint: This makes a lot of sense when you think about it, right? The muzzle of the cannon wraps around the rock, then you shoot the rock. Boom!
reading_mnemonic: You aim the <kanji>cannon</kanji> at your own <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう). You don't want to have a home anymore, you want to become a pirate, live on a boat, and (of course) shoot cannons all day long.
reading_hint: Watch as the cannon goes off, the rock hurtles into your home. And just like that, there is a huge, rock-shaped hole in it. You'll have to shoot a few more rocks at your home with this cannon before it's completely gone.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dragon</radical> radical is the same as this kanji, which is <kanji>dragon</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Not to <kanji>dragon</kanji> with it, but make sure you know your radicals so you know your kanji!
reading_mnemonic: Imagine a <kanji>dragon</kanji>. You are talking to it, which is already pretty strange, but as you're talking, he turns into the Street Fighter character <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう).
reading_hint: Then imagine after his transformation he attacks you using his Street Fighter moves. "Hadouken!"

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>bamboo</radical> thing you put on your head to <radical>stand</radical> taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a <kanji>conical hat</kanji>.
meaning_hint: You know the ones I'm talking about? They're cone-shaped, sort of, and they go on your head, keeping the sun off your face.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>conical hat</kanji> is kind of like an umbrella on your head. What's the reading for "umbrella" in Japanese? Why, it's <reading>kasa</reading> (かさ)!
reading_hint: Think about a bamboo umbrella on your head. They're pretty similar in shape, after all.

meaning_mnemonic: The part of <radical>rice</radical> that <radical>stand</radical>s up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the <kanji>grains</kanji>.
meaning_hint: If you think about this one it'll make good sense. Just imagine rice stalks standing up into the air.
reading_mnemonic: You have a box of <kanji>grains</kanji>. <reading>Ryuu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter is doing training by punching the grains to strengthen his fingers.
reading_hint: He has his hands flat, and stabs his hands into the grains. Yah! Yah! Yah!

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>thread</radical> tying <radical>wolverine</radical> to a <radical>pig</radical>, balancing them over the <kanji>edge</kanji> of a cliff together.
meaning_hint: Picture wolverine and a pig hanging precariously over the edge. One move the wrong way and they'll both go toppling over.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly, the pig squeals, pulls the thread, and sends them both over the <kanji>edge</kanji>. Straight to their <reading>en</reading>d (えん).
reading_hint: If you fall off the edge it'll be your end too. Always be safe and never get too close to any edges!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>feather</radical> is on a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, and they are attached <radical>together</radical>. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one <kanji>wing</kanji> of your amazing aircraft.
meaning_hint: Imagine a <kanji>wing</kanji> that is made of a rice paddy and a feather put together. Doesn't make sense, looks ugly, and probably will not fly. Imagine it anyways. It is your wing.
reading_mnemonic: To make the feather and rice paddy stick together you need some kind of sticking agent. This time we find the original bird that the feather came from and grab its eggs. We break the eggs open and use the <reading>yolk</reading> (よく). It's pretty sticky, but still probably not aircraft safe.
reading_hint: Imagine using the yolks to stick everything together. It's all over your hands, and things are pretty nasty.

meaning_mnemonic: Looking at the <radical>moon</radical>, you notice it's grown a bunch of <radical>branch</radical>es. Wait, are those all… <kanji>limbs</kanji>?!
meaning_hint: You feel absolutely terrified looking at the moon with all its branches consisting of limbs, lifelessly flopping around. How did this happen?
reading_mnemonic: After some consideration, you know who put all those <vocabulary>limb</vocabulary>s on the moon. It must've been none other than the moon <reading>shee</reading>p (し)!
reading_hint: The moon sheep are always up to no good, so this must all have been devised by them. Those darn moon sheep!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>fang</radical> is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little <kanji>sprout</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine a bunch of these. They look like big fangs poking out of the ground (that is, until they bloom and get into the air).
reading_mnemonic: When the <kanji>sprout</kanji> gets out of the ground and opens up, instead of a flower there is a human-looking <reading>目</reading> (め), looking right at you.
reading_hint: You look at all the sprouts. They have all turned into 目s, looking straight at you. You're terrified.

meaning_mnemonic: I <radical>say</radical>, which weighs more: a kilogram of <radical>scooter</radical>s or a kilogram of <radical>rice</radical>? This is a <kanji>riddle</kanji>!
meaning_hint: Think carefully and see if you can come up with the answer to my riddle before you read on.
reading_mnemonic: Did you figure out the answer to this <kanji>riddle</kanji>? Say your answer aloud to the screen right now.... <reading>not so</reading> (なぞ)! You're wrong.
reading_hint: Did you say the answer to the riddle is that they're both a kilogram? Not so! A scooter is heavier than some rice! And don't you email me saying that's not so! It's my riddle, I can make the answer whatever I want. That's the law of riddles!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gold</radical> <radical>pool</radical> is where you're going to go <kanji>fishing</kanji>. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself fishing in a gold pool, catching golden fish. What a great <kanji>fishing</kanji> spot this is.
reading_mnemonic: You caught a couple of gold fish. <reading>Two</reading> (つ) gold fish, actually!
reading_hint: Count your golden fish. They're so nice! They're also worth their weight in gold, because, well, they are gold.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> on a <radical>rice paddy</radical> means only one thing... <kanji>thunder</kanji>! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder!
meaning_hint: Imagine hearing the thunder closing in on you as you frantically try to escape the rice paddy. RUN!!!
reading_mnemonic: You can’t run fast enough to escape the <kanji>thunder</kanji>, so you decide to hide under a pile of… <reading>rye</reading> (らい)?!
reading_hint: This rye will save your life. It’s just you and this pile of rye now. Take a deeeeep breath in, and really smell the thunder and rye in the air. You’re fine. You’re cozy. This rye will be your savior.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>long</radical> <radical>hair</radical> is your <radical>friend</radical>. It's your <kanji>hair</kanji> and you're so proud of it.
meaning_hint: Just feel your hair, it's such a good friend, and you wish it was longer.
reading_mnemonic: Who gave you this hair? Probably the great <reading>神</reading> (かみ) of hair. You deserve this great hair.
reading_hint: Pretend to pray to the great hair 神. What is his reply? Does he give you more hair?
